revisions.rev:
{{Coord|35|43|8.57|N|51|23|30.60|E|display=title}} {{Infobox person |name = Neda Agha-Soltan |image = Neda Agha-Soltan.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = January 23, 1983 |birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] |death_date = June 20, 2009 (aged 26) |death_place = West of Kargar Avenue (proposed by some to be renamed Neda Street)Fathi, Nazila (June 22, 2009). [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/23/world/middleeast/23neda.html?ref=middleeast In a Death Seen Around the World, a Symbol of Iranian Protests]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. at the intersection between Khosravi and Salehi Streets,
[[Tehran]], [[Iran]] |death_cause = Firearm, according to the Iranian pro-Government media: [[Arash Hejazi]] or his friend;[http://www.irna.ir/View/FullStory/?NewsId=570612 Irna.ir]{{Dead link|date=March 2011}}[http://alef.ir/1388/content/view/58376/ Alef.ir] According to her family, eyewitness Hejazi: a person wearing the clothing of [[Basij]]. |resting_place = Behesht-e-Zahra cemetery, southern [[Tehran]] |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = Meshkini Street, [[Tehranpars]] neighborhood, [[Tehran]][http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,529086,00.html Neda Soltan's Family Reportedly Forced Out of Home by Iranian Authorities]. [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]. June 25, 2009. |nationality = {{flagicon|Iran}} [[Iran|Iranian]] |known_for = Death during the [[2009 Iranian election protests]] |alma_mater = [[Islamic Azad University]] (graduate, philosophy and religion)[http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/23/iran.neda.profile/index.html Who was Neda? Slain woman an unlikely martyr]; Guy Adams, CNN, 24 June 2009[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/election-outrage-that-turned-neda-into-a-political-protester-1715995.html Election outrage that turned Neda into a political protester]; Guy Adams, [[The Independent]], 24 June 2009 |employer = Family's [[travel agency]] |relations = Parents, one brother, one sister |party = Known as generally apolitical |footnotes = }} Footage of the '''death of Neda Agha-Soltan'''{{cite news|title=Neda Agha Soltan|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6562649.ece|last=Jenny|first=Booth|publisher=Times Newspapers Ltd.|location=News International Limited, 1 Virginia St, London E98 1XY|date=June 23, 2009|accessdate=June 23, 2009}} ({{lang-fa|ÙØ¯Ø§ Ø¢ÙØ§ Ø³ÙØ·Ø§Ù}} - ''NedÄ ÄÄ¡Ä SoltÄn''; January 23, 1983 – June 20, 2009) drew international attention after she was killed during the [[2009 Iranian election protests]].{{cite news|title=Neda: Latest iconic image to inspire|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/24/neda.iconic.images/|last=Ravitz|first=Jessica|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=June 24, 2009|accessdate=June 24, 2009}} Her death was captured on video by bystanders and broadcast over the Internet{{cite news |title='Neda' becomes rallying cry for Iranian protests |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=June 22, 2009 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/21/iran.woman.twitter/ |accessdate=June 24, 2009}} and the video became a rallying point for the opposition. It was described as "probably the most widely witnessed death in human history".{{cite news|title=Neda Agha-Soltan|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1945379_1944701_1944705,00.html|last=Mahr|first=Krista|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=December 8, 2009|accessdate=May 1, 2010}} ''NedÄ'' (ÙØ¯Ø§) is a word used in [[Persian language#Classic Persian|Classic Persian]] and modern [[Persian language|Persian]]'''ÙØ¯Ø§''' has been borrowed from the same [[Classical Arabic]] word (a verb in Arabic) meaning âget togetherâ , âmeet withâ , then âgatherâ, âcome togetherâ, âcall togetherâ, ârallyâ. It is a synonym of ''Ø§Ø¬ØªÙØ¹''. A lot more meanings are given in dictionaries like ''WÃ¶rterbuch der Klassischen Arabischen Sprache (Dictionary of Classical Arabic)'', by Manfred Ullmann, Edward William Lane, the Arabic and Persian ''Moungued dictionaries - ÙÙØ§ÙÙØ³ Ø§ÙÙÙØ¬Ø¯'' and many more. to mean âvoiceâ, calling (sometimes understood as a âdivine messageâ, but this is not the etymological sense of ''ÙØ¯Ø§''), and she has been referred to as the "voice of Iran".{{cite news |issn=0040-718X |last=Chua-eoan |first=Howard |title=What the World Didn't See in Tehran |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=June 21, 2009 |date=June 21, 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1906040,00.html }}{{cite news|title=Iran TV says 10 died in protests|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=June 21, 2009|date=June 21, 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8111352.stm|quote=Witness accounts on Saturday suggested police used live rounds, batons, tear gas, and water cannon to break up demonstrations that went on late into the night. Among unconfirmed material posted on the internet after Saturday's protests, a brief graphic video clip appearing to show a teenage girl dying from a wound, has fueled anti-government feelings. The girl, who has been called Neda, had been protesting with her father in Tehran when she was shot.}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/us_world/2009/06/21/2009-06-21_neda_young_girl_killed_in_iraq.html |title=Neda, young girl killed in Iran, becoming symbol of rebellion |work=[[New York Daily News]] |last=Kennedy |first=Helen |date=June 22, 2009 |accessdate=June 24, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Her death became iconic in the struggle of Iranian protesters against the disputed election of President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]]. == Biography == Agha-Soltan was the middle child of a [[middle class]] family of three children, whose family resided in a fourth floor flat on Meshkini Street in the [[Tehranpars]] district of Tehran.Correspondent in Tehran (June 24, 2009). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jun/24/neda-soltan-iran-family-forced-out Neda Soltan's family 'forced out of home' by Iranian authorities]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Her father is a civil servant and her mother is a homemaker. She graduated from [[Islamic Azad University]], where she had studied Islamic theology as well as secular philosophies.Connett, David (June 28, 2009). [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iran-online-around-the-world-in-60-minutes-1722467.html Iran online: Around the world in 60 minutes]. ''[[The Independent]]''. She was divorced, and according to her mother, had difficulty finding work because of how employers perceived her.Wayne Drash and Octavia Nasr (November 5, 2009). [http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/11/05/neda.mom.speaks/index.html Neda's mother: She was 'like an angel']. ''[[CNN]]''. Agha-Soltan was an aspiring, [[underground music|underground]] [[musician]], who was studying her craft through private voice and music lessons.Women in Iran are legally prohibited from singing in the presence of men; nonetheless, an underground market exists for CDs of such music. The ban on men includes male sound technicians, who must vacate before the performance beginsMay, Rachel (August 22, 2003). [http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/0822/p08s02-wome.html In Iran, no men allowed at women's music fest]. ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''. She had studied the violin and had an as-yet-undelivered piano on order at the time of her death.{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/23/iran.neda.profile/index.html | work=CNN | title=Who was Neda? Slain woman an unlikely martyr - CNN.com | accessdate=May 1, 2010 | date=June 24, 2009}} She worked for her family's travel agencyFarber, Daniel (June 23, 2009). [http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2009/06/23/world/worldwatch/entry5106343.shtml Neda: More Than An Icon]. [[CBS News]]. Agha-Soltan enjoyed travelling, having saved up money to go on package tours with her friends to [[Dubai]], [[Thailand]] and [[Turkey]]. She had studied [[Turkish language|Turkish]], hoping it would aid her as a guide for Iranians on foreign tours in Turkey.{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jun/22/neda-soltani-death-iran |title=How Neda Soltani became the face of Iran's struggle |last=Tait |first=Robert |coauthors=Weaver, Matthew |date=June 22, 2009 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=June 23, 2009 | location=London}} It was in Turkey, two months prior to her death, that she met her fiancÃ©, 37-year-old Caspian Makan, who worked as a photojournalist in [[Tehran]]. Those who knew her maintain that Agha-Soltan had not previously been very political â she had not supported any particular candidate in the 2009 Iran elections{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/13/iran-demonstrations-viole_n_215189.html |title=Iran updates (video): Live-blogging the uprising |work=[[Huffington Post]] |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 24, 2009 |last=Pitney |first=Nico}} â but that anger over the election results prompted her to join the protest. Her [[voice teacher|voice]] and [[music teacher]], Hamid Panahi, who was accompanying Agha-Soltan during the protest and can be seen on the video trying to comfort the dying woman, told the media: "She couldn't stand the injustice of it." Panahi went on to state: "All she wanted was the proper vote of the people to be counted. She wanted to show with her presence that, 'I'm here, I also voted, and my vote wasn't counted', although her family has stated that she attempted to vote and didn't because no representatives of any other parties than the incumbent were present, "It was a very peaceful act of protest, without any violence." Her name is often miscited as "Neda Soltani". Neda Soltani is a different woman, whose Facebook profile photo was mistakenly published in many articles about the incident. She tried in vain to remove her photo from the internet. Finally, Neda Soltani had to flee from Iran and was granted asylum in Germany in 2010.{{de icon}} David Schraven, [http://sz-magazin.sueddeutsche.de/texte/anzeigen/32571 ''Das zweite Leben der Neda Soltani''], SÃ¼ddeutsche Zeitung Magazin, Heft 05/2010. Consulted on February 6, 2010.[http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iPD-wzCdHuXjid8AqB2gs2iqtn7Q ''Iranian mistaken for 'Neda' seeks German asylum''], AFP. Consulted on February 6, 2010.[http://www.anorak.co.uk/214504/media/neda-soltani-is-alive.html Anorak.co.uk] == Circumstances of her death == On June 20, 2009, at around 6:30 p.m., Neda Agha-Soltan was sitting in her [[Peugeot 206]] in traffic on [[Kargar Avenue]] in the city of [[Tehran]]. She was accompanied by her music teacher and close friend, Hamid Panahi, and two others, who remain unidentified.{{cite news |last=Daragahi |first=Borzou |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-neda23-2009jun23,0,366975,full.story |title=Family, friends mourn 'Neda,' Iranian woman who died on video |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 23, 2009|accessdate=June 23, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/23/world/middleeast/23neda.html |title=In a death seen around the world, a symbol of Iranian protests |last=Fathi |first=Nazila |date=June 22, 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=June 24, 2009}} The four were on their way to participate in the protests against the outcome of the [[2009 Iranian presidential election]].{{cite news|title=Neda Agha Soltanâs story touches everyone except Iranâs rulers|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6565497.ece|work=The Times|date=2009-06-2004|accessdate=2009-06-2004 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher}} The car's air conditioner was not working well, so she stopped her car some distance from the main protests and got out on foot to escape the heat. She was standing and observing the sporadic protests in the area when she was shot in the chest.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8113552.stm |title=Death video woman 'targeted by militia'|date=June 22, 2009|accessdate=June 24, 2009|publisher=[[BBC News]]}} As captured on amateur video, she collapsed to the ground and was tended to by a doctor, her music teacher, and others from the crowd. Someone in the crowd around her shouted, "She has been shot! Someone, come and take her!"{{cite news|title=Who was Neda? Slain woman an unlikely martyr|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/23/iran.neda.profile/index.html#cnnSTCText|date=7:24 a.m. EDT, Wed June 24, 2009|accessdate=June 28, 2009 | work=CNN}} The videos were accompanied by a message from a doctor, later identified as Dr. [[Arash Hejazi]], who said he had been present during the incident (but has since fled Iran out of fear of government reprisals):{{cite news|title=Doctor flees Iran over "Neda" killing|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE55P1IZ20090626|publisher=Reuters|date=June 26, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2009}}
At 19:05 June 20th Place: Kargar Ave., at the corner crossing Khosravi St. and Salehi st. A young woman who was standing aside with her father [sic, later identified as her music teacher] watching the protests was shot by a Basij member hiding on the rooftop of a civilian house. He had clear shot at the girl and could not miss her. However, he aimed straight at her heart. I am a doctor, so I rushed to try to save her. But the impact of the gunshot was so fierce that the bullet had blasted inside the victimâs chest, and she died in less than two minutes. The protests were going on about one kilometre away in the main street and some of the protesting crowd were running from tear gas used among them, towards Salehi St. The film is shot by my friend who was standing beside me.{{cite news |url=http://blogs.usatoday.com/ondeadline/2009/06/in-.html |title=In Iran, one woman â Neda â becomes a symbol |date=June 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 24, 2009 |publisher=[[USA Today]] |last=DeRoy |first=Glenna}}
Her last words were, "I'm burning, I'm burning!", according to Panahi. She died en route to Tehran's Shariati hospital.{{cite news |title=Neda Agha Soltan |work=[[The Times]] |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 24, 2009 |first=Jenny |last=Booth |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6562649.ece | location=London}} However, the civilian physician that tended to Neda in the video has stated that Neda died on the scene.{{youtube|id=C4-iLG6FwRc22|title=Neda : An Iranian Martyr [BBC Documentary]}}{{youtube|id=mYN53BOeijY|title=HBO The True Story of Neda Agha-Soltan Ø²ÙØ¯Ú¯Ù ÙØ¯Ø§ Ø¢ÙØ§ Ø³ÙØ·Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Ù}} Hejazi, standing one metre away from her when she was shot, tried to stanch her wound with his hands. Hejazi said nearby members of the crowd pulled a man from his motorcycle while shouting: "We got him, we got him," disarmed him, obtained his identity card and identified him as a member of the [[Basij]] militia (government paramilitary). The militiaman was shouting, "I didn't want to kill her." The protesters let him go, but they kept the alleged killer's identity card and took many photographs of him.According to an eye-witness, Dr. Arash Hejazi; see [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8119713.stm News.bbc.co.uk] A recent documentary on the shooting contained a previously unseen clip of demonstrators capturing the militiaman seconds after the shooting.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6917831.ece Times Online] Logically we therefore cannot deduce whether Neda was shot from the rooftop or from the street hence questioning the apparent witness accounts. == Videos == {{See also|Role of the Internet during 2009 Iranian election protests}} [[File:Neda non graphic.jpg|thumb|A frame from the video of Agha-Soltan's death by gunfire]] The videos spread across the internet [[Viral video|virally]], quickly gaining the attention of international media and viewers.Langendonck, Gert Van (June 23, 2009). [http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2280315.ece/Iconic_Iran_video_was_posted_in_the_Netherlands Iconic Iran video was posted in the Netherlands]. ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]''. Discussions about the incident on [[Twitter]], using a [[hashtag]] of #neda, became one of the "'trending topics'" by the end of the day on June 20, 2009. The incident was not originally reported by the state-controlled Iranian media, but was instead first reported on by international media. The video has been shown on [[CNN]] and other news networks.{{cite web |title=Youtube - Neda's Death Becomes Iranian Symbol: News Current |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZmrB2FOLqiE|accessdate=December 7, 2010}} There are three videos depicting her death. One shows her collapsing to the ground, apparently still conscious.{{cite web |title=Young girl being killed by plain-clothes |accessdate=June 22, 2009 |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=0db_1245519048 |publisher=[[LiveLeak]]}} The second shows her only after she appears to lose consciousness and begins to bleed heavily.{{cite web |title=Girl shot by police â Second Angle|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=fe5_1245534854 |accessdate=June 22, 2009 |publisher=[[LiveLeak]]}} The third video shows her just as she begins to bleed profusely.{{cite web |title=Iran - New Footage of Neda's Death ( Graphic ) - Third Angle|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=b1d_1276271267 |accessdate=June 17, 2010 |publisher=[[LiveLeak]]}} In the first video, the cameraman approaches a group of people huddled together in front of a parked car at the side of the street. As he moves closer, she can be seen collapsing to the pavement with a large bloodstain at her feet. Two men, Hamid Panahi and Arash Hejazi, are seen trying to revive her. The elderly Panahi was initially assumed to be her father, but later confirmed to be her music teacher. As seconds pass, her eyes roll to one side and she appears to lose consciousness. Blood begins to pour from her nose and mouth, and screams are heard. In the second video, the cameraman approaches her and the two men; the camera passes over them and centers on her face; her stare is blank and she is bleeding profusely from her nose and mouth. Loud screaming can be heard. The man next to her can apparently be heard speaking in the first video, saying her name:
Neda, don't be afraid. Neda, don't be afraid. [obscured by others yelling] Neda, stay with me. Neda stay with me!
The videos were awarded the [[George Polk Award]] for Videography for 2009.{{cite news |title=Anonymous video of Neda Aghan-Soltan's death wins Polk award|last=Bunz|first=Mercedes|publisher=[[The Guardian]]: PDA The Digital Content Blog|date=February 16, 2010 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/pda/2010/feb/16/george-polk-awards/ |accessdate=June 13, 2010 | location=London}} == Alleged killer == The man accused of killing Neda Soltan has been identified as Abbas Kargar Javid, a pro-government militiaman, after photographs of the Basijiâs ID cards appeared on the internet, according to ''The Times''.{{cite news|title=The face of Abbas Kargar Javid â man accused of killing Neda Soltan|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6802669.ece|accessdate=21 May 2011|newspaper=The Times|date=August 20, 2009|author=Martin Fletcher|location=London}} == Aftermath == [[File:Grave of Neda.jpg|thumb|left|185px|Grave site immediately following burial]] After being pronounced dead at Shariati hospital, Agha-Soltan was buried at the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] cemetery in southern Tehran; she was denied a proper funeral by government authorities.{{cite news |url=http://www.agi.it/world/news/200906221348-pol-ren0027-iran_funeral_prohibited_for_neda_demonstration_at_4pm|publisher=[[Agenzia Giornalistica Italia]]|title=Iran: Funeral prohibited for Neda, demonstration at 4PM|date=June 22, 2009|accessdate=June 22, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news |last=Weissenstein |first=Michael |last2=Johnson |first2=Anna |title=Amateur video turns woman into icon of Iran unrest |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=June 22, 2009 |date=June 22, 2009 |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090622/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election_icon |publisher=[[Yahoo News]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The authorities had allegedly set aside empty graves for those killed during the protests. Her family agreed to the removal of her organs for [[organ transplant|transplanting]] to medical patients. The Iranian government has issued a ban on collective prayers in mosques for Agha-Soltan in the aftermath of the incident.{{cite news|last=McElroy|first=Damien|title=Iran bans prayers for 'Angel of Freedom' Neda Agha-Soltan |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|accessdate=June 24, 2009|date=June 22, 2009|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/5603057/Iran-bans-prayers-for-Angel-of-Freedom-Neda-Agha-Soltan.html | location=London}} Soona Samsami, the executive director of the Women's Freedom Forum, who has been relaying information about the protests inside Iran to the international media, told the foreign press that Agha-Soltan's immediate family were threatened by authorities if they permitted a gathering to mourn her.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,528441,00.html|title=Iran's 'angel of freedom' Neda Soltan vowed to protest against injustice|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=June 23, 2009|accessdate=June 24, 2009}} Samsami stated, "They were threatened that if people wanted to gather there the family would be charged and punished." Caspian Makan (Agha-Soltan's fiancÃ©) told BBC: "Neda had said that even if she lost her life and got a bullet in her heart, she would carry on".{{cite news| last=Sheikholeslami |first=Ali |coauthors= Alexander, Caroline |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aHvSY8wNfM_M| title=Nedaâs killing propels Iranâs women to more opposition protests |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=23 June 2009}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and other news sources have speculated that due to the widespread attention given to Agha-Soltan's story by [[social media]] networks and mainstream news organizations, she is already being hailed as a [[martyr]]. There is also speculation that the [[Shia Islam|Shi'ite]] cycle of [[mourning]] on the third (June 23), seventh (June 27), and 40th (July 30) day after a person's death may give the protests sustained momentum, in similar fashion to the [[Iranian Revolution]], where each commemoration of a demonstrator's death sparked renewed protests, resulting in more deaths, feeding a cycle that eventually resulted in the overthrowing of [[Pahlavi dynasty|Iran's monarchy]].{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Robin |title=In Iran, one woman's death may have many consequences |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=June 23, 2009 |date=June 21, 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1906049,00.html}} On June 22, Iranian presidential candidates [[Mehdi Karroubi]] and [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]], who are contesting the validity of the election of [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], called upon Iranian citizens to commemorate Agha-Soltan. Karroubi announced his appeal on Facebook, asking demonstrators to gather in the center of the Iranian capital at 4:00 pm local time. The chief of the Tehran Police announced that his department had no involvement in the fatal incident.Hendelman-Baavur, Liora (June 25, 2009). [http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1245184921949&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Analysis: Hell hath no fury]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. Later that day, riot police armed with [[live ammunition]] and tear gas dispersed a crowd of between 200 and 1,000 protesters who had gathered in [[Tehran]]'s Haft-e Tir Square. The protests followed online calls for tribute to Agha-Soltan and others killed during the demonstrations.{{cite news|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090623/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election|title=Iran's top electoral body rules out vote annulment people in Tehran's Haft-e Tir square after on-line calls for protesters to pay tribute to Neda|date=June 23, 2009|accessdate=June 23, 2009|last=Kole|first=William J.|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Yahoo News]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} [[Grand Ayatollah Hossein-Ali Montazeri]], a senior Iranian cleric and vocal critic of [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], called for three days of public mourning for the death of Neda. Caspian Makan, following Neda's death, was [[torture]]d and escaped to [[Canada.]] He recently visited [[Israel]] as a guest of Israel's [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]]. "I have come here out of the brotherhood of nations," he told Channel 2.[http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=171380 ''Neda's fiance: Iran will be free.'' [[Jerusalem Post]] March 19, 2010] === Funeral === About 70 mourners gathered outside Niloufar mosque in [[Abbas Abad]], where the Agha-Soltan family attended services. A leaflet posted on the mosque's door read, "There is no commemoration here for Neda Agha Soltan." Many in the crowd wore black. Some recited poems. After about ten minutes, 20 Basij paramilitary arrived on motorcycles and dispersed the attendees.[http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/06/the-world-mourns-neda.html Political Punch]; ABC News, 23 June 2009 On June 24, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported the results of interviews of neighbours who said Agha-Soltan's family had been forced to vacate their apartment some days after her death.{{cite news|title=Neda Soltan's family 'forced out of home' by Iranian authorities|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=June 24, 2009|accessdate=June 24, 2009|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jun/24/neda-soltan-iran-family-forced-out | location=London}} [[Reuters]] reported that supporters of presidential candidate [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] stated they would release thousands of balloons on Friday, June 26, 2009 with the message "Neda you will always remain in our hearts" imprinted on them.[http://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE55F54520090625?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews Reuters: ''Ahmadinejad compares Obama to Bush''. June 24, 2009] Retrieved June 24, 2009 On June 23, it was reported that, to prevent Agha-Soltan's family's home from becoming a place of pilgrimage, government authorities told the family to remove the black mourning banners from outside the home.{{cite news|title=Iranian authorities scramble to negate Neda Soltan 'martyrdom'|work=[[The Times]]|date=June 23, 2009|accessdate=June 24, 2009|first=Jenny|last=Booth|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6561253.ece | location=London}} On Friday, July 31, 2009, 40th day anniversary of the killings of such youth as Neda Agha Soltan, [[Sohrab Aarabi]] and Ashkan Sohrabi was held in Tehran where thousands of Iranians mourned for the loss of the victims.{{cite news|title=Iran witnesses: Neda memorial |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8176961.stm|date=July 31, 2009|accessdate=December 7, 2010|work=[[BBC]]}} Reports also came of gatherings in the thousands in cities of [[Rasht]], [[Shiraz]] and Mashad.{{cite news|title=IRAN: Footage emerges from demonstrations across the country|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/07/iran-footage-emerges-from-demonstrations-across-the-country.html|date=July 31, 2009|accessdate=December 7, 2010|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=Smith|first=Amber|location=Los Angeles}} ===Desecration of her grave=== [[File:Graveyard.jpg|thumb|photo by Arash Nikkhah 2011]] On November 16, 2009, supporters of the Iranian regime desecrated her grave and removed her gravestone. Later, on December 31, 2009, supporters of the Iranian Government defaced the portrait on her grave by shooting at it multiple times.{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6979914.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Neda Soltans grave defaced as Iran issues new internet restrictions | first=Martin | last=Fletcher | date=January 8, 2010 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}} ===Iranian government reactions=== The university branch of female members of [[Basij]] held a gathering in Tehran in front of the British embassy, demanding that [[Arash Hejazi]] be returned to Iran (as witness or suspect). As they are assumed to be close to the government, it means the government condemns the crime and is pursuing it (their way). According to an Iranian official, announcing her as a martyr is possible. Iran's ambassador to [[Mexico]], Mohammad Hassan Ghadiri, suggested in an interview on June 25, 2009 that the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] could have been involved in Agha-Soltan's death. Ambassador Ghadiri questioned how the shooting was video taped so effectively, asserting that the incident occurred away from other demonstrations. He also stated that using a woman would be more effective in accomplishing the goals the CIA is purported to desire.Malcom, Andrew (June 25, 2009). [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/06/neda-cia-cnn-killing.html Iran ambassador suggests CIA could have killed Neda Agha-Soltan]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Ambassador Ghadiri said "the bullet that was found in her head was not a bullet that you could find in Iran" (he thought she was shot in head). The account of Doctor Hejazi was that Agha-Soltan was shot in the chest from the front, as there was no exit wound, and the video evidence showing a wound to the chest.{{Cite news | title = Iran doctor tells of Neda's death | work = BBC | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | date = 2009-06-25 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8119713.stm }} Hejazi is the man seen in the video placing his hands on Agha-Soltan's chest to staunch her bleeding (as described above under section [[#Circumstances of death|Circumstances of death]]). During his Friday sermon on June 26, the [[Ali Khamenei|Supreme Leader]]'s appointed speaker Ayatollah [[Ahmad Khatami]] said "evidence shows that [protesters] have done it themselves and have raised propaganda against the system."{{Cite news | last = Erdbrink | first = Thomas | coauthors = William Branigin | title = Iranian cleric says protesters wage war against God | work = The Boston Globe | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | date = 2009-06-27 | url = http://www.boston.com/news/world/middleeast/articles/2009/06/27/iranian_cleric_says_protesters_wage_war_against_god/ }} Eye witnesses at the scene of the shooting said Agha-Soltan was shot by a member of the pro-government [[Basij]] militia.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8113552.stm Death video woman 'targeted by militia']. [[BBC News]]. June 22, 2009.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8119713.stm Iran doctor tells of Neda's death]. [[BBC News]]. June 25, 2009.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/23/2606131.htm Basij militia 'targeting women']. [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]. June 23, 2009. Some of the eye-witnesses say she was shot from the ground, some say from the rooftop. Iran's police chief, brigadier general Ahmadi-Moghaddam told the press on June 30, 2009 that the Iranian police and [[Ministry of Intelligence and National Security of Iran|Ministry of Intelligence]] filed an arrest warrant for [[Interpol]] to arrest Dr. Arash Hejazi, an eyewitness of Neda's death, for poisoning the international atmosphere against the Iranian government and telling misinformation about Neda's death by giving his account of the incident to foreign news media.{{Cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2009/07/090701_ka_ir88_hejazi_ahmadimoghadam.shtml| title=ÙØ±ÙØ§ÙØ¯Ù ÙÛØ±ÙÛ Ø§ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙÛ: Ø´Ø§ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ú¯ ÙØ¯Ø§ ØªØ­Øª ØªØ¹ÙÛØ¨ ÙØ²Ø§Ø±Øª Ø§Ø·ÙØ§Ø¹Ø§Øª Ù Ù¾ÙÛØ³ Ø¨ÛÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§Ø³Øª| language=[[Persian language|Persian]]| publisher=[[BBC Persian]]}} [[Ezzatollah Zarghami]], the head of [[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting]], told the press on July 4, 2009 that the videos of Neda's death were all made by [[BBC]] and [[CNN]].{{Cite news| url=http://tabannews.net/totla.php?id=4642|title= Ø¶Ø±ØºØ§ÙÛ: Ø¯Ø± Ø§ÙØªØ®Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª ÙÙØ²ÙØ¦ÙØ§ ÙÙ ÛÚ© ÙÙØ± ÙØ«Ù "ÙØ¯Ø§" Ø±Ø§ Ú©Ø´ØªÙØ¯!| language=[[Persian language|Persian]]| publisher=Taban News}}{{Cite news| url=http://www.iranuk88.com/article.php?id=39219|title= Ø§Ø¯Ø¹Ø§Ù Ø¹Ø¬ÙØ¨ Ø¶Ø±ØºØ§ÙÙ: ØªØµÙÙØ± ÙØªÙ ÙØ¯Ø§ Ø¢ÙØ§Ø³ÙØ·Ø§Ù Ø³Ø§Ø®ØªÚ¯Ù Ø§Ø³Øª| language=[[Persian language|Persian]]| publisher=Iranian Uk.com}}{{Cite news| url=http://www.ayandenews.com/fa/pages/?cid=9643|title= Ø¶Ø±ØºØ§ÙÛ:Ø¯Ø± ÙÙØ²ÙØ¦ÙØ§ ÙÙ ÙØ¯Ø§ Ú©Ø´ØªÙØ¯ ØªØ§ Ø¨Ú¯ÙÛÙØ¯ Ø±Ø§Û ÚØ§ÙØ² ÙÙ Ø³Ø§Ø®ØªÚ¯Û Ø§Ø³Øª| language=[[Persian language|Persian]]| publisher=Ayandenews.com}} In November 2009, Iran's embassy in London sent a letter of protest to [[The Queen's College, Oxford]] about the college establishing the [[Neda Agha-Soltan Graduate Scholarship]] in Philosophy.{{Cite news| url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g6AZA1tCAKUr-s6fNAG9gfKpZMkwD9BTGBP03 | title=Iran condemns Oxford for honoring slain protester | author=Ali Akbar Dareini | publisher=Associated Press | date=12 November 2009}} In December 2009, Iranian state television aired a report about Agha-Soltan's death, portraying it as a western plot. The program argued that Agha-Soltan simulated her death with accomplices, and that she was killed afterwards, having no knowledge of her partners' intentions.{{youtube|id=Shp7HE2YA_c|title=Nedas Death - The other Side of the Coin,''Press TV''}} ====Claims of forced confessions==== According to The Times, quoted from Mr. Makan and Ms. Agha Soltan's parents, officials tried to get them to confess that it was opposition protestors that had killed Neda, and not government militiamen. They were given incentives such as declaring Neda to be a martyr and giving the family a pension if they complied. Mr. Makan and Neda's family refused the offer. Mr. Panahi was later forced by the government to change his story. The new version of events were retold by Panahi on state television.[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/deathintehran/view/ A Death in Tehran], at PBS ====Response to the Iranian government==== In December 2009, her family accused the security forces of killing her. This was the strongest statement the family of Neda Agha-Soltan made since her death. This accusation followed the spread of an Iranian government-proposed theory blaming a ''"conspiracy of western governments"'' for the killing. ''"I openly declare that no one, apart from the government, killed Neda. Her killer can only be from the government,"'' her father told the BBC's Persian service by telephone from Iran.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8396052.stm "Neda Agha-Soltan's family accuse Iran of her killing"] ===Oxford Graduate Scholarship=== {{Main|Neda Agha-Soltan Graduate Scholarship}} The Neda Agha-Soltan Graduate Scholarship is a [[scholarship]] for post-graduate philosophy students at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]], with preference given to students of [[Iran]]ian citizenship or heritage. The college received offers from two anonymous donors to establish a scholarship, followed by many individual donations from members of the public and former students of Queen's. The college aims to raise Â£65,000 to establish the scholarship on a permanent basis. The first recipient of the scholarship is Arianne Shahvis, a philosophy student of Iranian descent, who described the award as "a great honour". ==See also== {{Portal box|Iran|Death}} * [[Sohrab Aarabi]] * [[Taraneh Mousavi]] * [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] * [[Death of Hamza Ali Al-Khateeb]] {{-}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{youtube|id=YN-VIxONSbA|title=Documentary investigating the death of Neda Agha-Soltan, with pictures and witness accounts}} * [http://www.liu.edu/Brooklyn/About/News/Newsletters/~/media/Files/Brooklyn/About/NewsEvents/BrooklynBeat/BBspring2010.ashx Video of her death wins prestigious 2009 George Polk Award for Videography] * [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/nov/15/iran-neda-caspian-makan-interview Caspian Makan: 'I cannot believe it yet. I still think I will see Neda again']; The Guardian, 15 November 2009 * [http://www.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,1906549,00.html Photos: Who Was Neda Agha-Soltan?] â a photo essay by ''TIME'' * [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/5603057/Iran-bans-prayers-for-Angel-of-Freedom-Neda-Agha-Soltan.html Iran Bans Prayers for 'Angel of Freedom' Neda Agha Soltan]; Damien McElroy, The Telegraph, 22 June 2009 * [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-neda23-2009jun23,0,366975,full.story Family, Friends Mourn 'Neda']; Borzou Daragahi, Los Angeles Times, 23 June 2009 * [http://www.thisisforneda.com/ ''For Neda'':] A 67min documentary film by the British film-maker [[Antony Thomas]] - public release on 14 June 2010. [http://www.youtube.com/user/ThisIsForNeda Film available in youtube in English, Persian and Arabic language.] * [http://en.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-310/_nr-762/i.html Neda, an Opera by Nader Mashayekhi: Pathos without Kitsch] {{Green Movement}} {{Iranian presidential election, 2009 footer}} {{Persondata | NAME = Neda Agha-Soltan | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = January 23, 1983 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | DATE OF DEATH = June 20, 2009 | PLACE OF DEATH = West of Kargar Avenue (proposed by some to be renamed Neda Street) at the intersection between Khosravi and Salehi Streets, [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Death of Neda Agha-Soltan}} [[Category:2009 deaths|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Iran|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Deaths by person|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Filmed deaths|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Iranian presidential election, 2009]] [[Category:Protest-related deaths|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Anti-Iranian sentiments|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Protests in Iran]] [[Category:1983 births]] [[af:Neda]] [[als:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[ar:ÙÙØªÙ ÙØ¯Ø§ Ø¢ØºØ§ Ø³ÙØ·Ø§Ù]] [[bs:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[bg:Ð¡Ð¼ÑÑÑÑÐ° Ð½Ð° ÐÐµÐ´Ð° ÐÐ³Ð°-Ð¡Ð¾Ð»ÑÐ°Ð½]] [[ca:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[cs:NedÃ¡ ÃghÃ¡-SoltÃ¡n]] [[da:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[de:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[el:Î Î´Î¿Î»Î¿ÏÎ¿Î½Î¯Î± ÏÎ·Ï Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[es:Neda Agha Soltan]] [[eo:Murdo de Neda Aga-Soltan]] [[fa:ÙØ¯Ø§ Ø¢ÙØ§Ø³ÙØ·Ø§Ù]] [[fr:Affaire Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[it:Morte di Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[he:×¤×¨×©×ª ×××ª× ×©× × ×× ×××-×¡×××××]] [[la:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[hu:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[arz:ÙØ¯Ø§ Ø§ØºØ§ Ø³ÙØ·Ø§Ù]] [[nl:Dood van Neda Soltan]] [[no:Neda]] [[pl:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[pt:Neda Agha-Soltan]] [[ru:ÐÐ³Ð°-Ð¡Ð¾Ð»ÑÐ°Ð½, ÐÐµÐ´Ð°]] [[fi:Neda Soltan]] [[tr:Nida AÄa-Sultan'Ä±n Ã¶lÃ¼mÃ¼]] [[vi:CÃ¡i cháº¿t cá»§a Neda Agha-Soltan]]
